questions.question: Which muscle is implicated in ptosis in Horner syndrome?
questions.explanation: muscle, a smooth muscle responsible for a minor portion of upper eyelid retraction. Incorrect Options: Options B, C, and D are not responsible for causing ptosis in Horner’s syndrome.

questions.question: What is the recommended treatment for a patient with Bell's palsy, who is experiencing symptoms of dry eye, redness, and irritation, along with the presence of multiple punctate epithelial erosions in the cornea as observed through a slit lamp examination?
questions.explanation: presents with dry eye, redness, and irritation, along with multiple punctate epithelial erosions in the cornea, the most appropriate management option is Tarsorrhaphy. It is a surgical procedure in which the eyelids are partially sewn together to reduce the exposure of the cornea. Paralytic Ectropion: Cause: Facial nerve palsy (Bell’s), Trauma/surgery Clinical Feature: Exposure keratopathy Treatment: Temporary measures: Topical lubricants, eyelid taping, suture tarsorrhaphy . Permanent measures (if needed): Horizontal lid tightening with/without middle lamellar buttress, palpebral sling operation Incorrect Options: Contact lens (Option B) As the cornea is already eroded contact lenses should be avoided Corneal replacement (Option C) , such as corneal transplantation or corneal grafting is not recommended because Bell's palsy will result in exposure keratopathy. LASIK (Option D) (laser-assisted in situ keratomileusis) is a refractive surgery procedure used to correct myopia, hyperopia, and astigmatism. Reference: Yanoff & Duker - Ophthalmology 5th edition, page- 1287,1288

questions.question: Identify the instrument.
questions.explanation: there is a solid blade (to be kept externally on the skin). There is a ring-shaped blade that needs to be placed on the inner conjunctival surface. The handle has a thumbscrew, which can be tightened and released to achieve the required pressure. There is a forceps-like handle. After aligning the position to enclose the chalazion in the ring, the clamp is tightened and fixed. Evisceration spatula (Option A) Used for removing only intraocular contents leaving the sclera and muscles of the eye intact. Enucleation spoon (Option C) Used to remove entire intraocular contents from the eye socket leaving the lining and muscle of the eye intact.

questions.question: What is the term for the additional row of eyelashes located behind the grey line?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Distichiasis Explanation: The case is of distichiasis - extra eyelash row Eyelash rubbing the cornea can happen in: Trichiasis - Inward misdirection of lashes with the normal position of the lid margin (Option A ruled out) Pseudotrichiasis - Inward turning of lashes along with the lid margin Distichiasis - Extra row of eyelash (Option B) Clinical features Foreign body sensation Photophobia Irritation Pain Lacrimation Reflex blepharospasm and photophobia (if the cornea is abraded) Conjunctival congestion Complications Recurrent corneal abrasions Superficial corneal opacities Corneal vascularization Non-healing corneal ulcer Treatment Epilation Electrolysis Cryoepilation Surgical correction Tylosis (Option C) is a genetic condition characterized by thickening of the lid margin. Madarosis (Option D) refers to the loss or absence of eyelashes and/or eyebrows

questions.question: What is the most frequently occurring tumor found in the lacrimal gland?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) Pleomorphic adenoma Explanation: Pleomorphic adenoma is the most frequently occurring tumour of the lacrimal gland. Most commons: Tumor of lacrimal gland (Overall/ Benign) Pleomorphic adenoma (Option C) Malignant tumor of Lacrimal gland Adenoid cystic > Mucoepidermoid carcinoma Benign intraocular tumor - Adults Cavernous hemangioma Malignant intraocular tumor - Adults Lymphoma Benign intraocular tumor - Children Dermoid Malignant intraocular tumor - Children Rhabdomyosarcoma Reference: Parsons Diseases of the Eye 23rd Edition, Page 424-427.

questions.question: An 11-month-old baby was brought by his mother with complaints of the left upper eyelid moving up and down while breastfeeding that disappears when the baby is not breastfeeding. She gave a history of the child being diagnosed with left eye ptosis. What is this condition called?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: D) Marcus -Gunn jaw-winking Explanation: The clinical presentation is suggestive of Marcus-Gunn jaw winking ptosis , characterised by retraction of the ptotic lid with jaw movements due to stimulation of ipsilateral pterygoid muscle. Congenital synkinetic ptosis (Marcus Gunn jaw-winking ptosis): Retraction of the ptotic lid with jaw movements due to stimulation of ipsilateral pterygoid muscle. It occurs due to trigemino-oculomotor synkinesis. The pathophysiology of Marcus Gunn Jaw winking phenomenon is a congenital misdirection of mandibular branch of trigeminal nerve , i.e., this synkinetic movement results from a congenital aberrant connection between motor branches of the trigeminal nerve controlling muscles of mastication and superior division of the oculomotor nerve controlling the levator palpebrae superioris. Symblepharon (Option A): Symblepharon is the adhesion between the palpebral and bulbar conjunctiva due to burns, chemical injuries, surgery, and ulcer. Blepharophimosis syndrome (Option B): Blepharophimosis syndrome is a congenital anomaly characterized by blepharophimosis (decreased horizontal length), ptosis , congenital ectropion , and telecanthus . Lagophthalmos (Option C): Lagophthalmos is the inability to close the eyelids voluntarily . Reference: Kanski’s Clinical Ophthalmology 9th edition page 77-78 https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK56868 8/#:~:text=Congenital%20ptosis%20is%20the%20presence,can%20be%20unilateral%20or%20bilateral

questions.question: In the context of medical treatment, the V-Y procedure is employed for which of the subsequent conditions?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Ectropion Explanation: The V-Y procedure is used in the management of mild cases of Cicatricial Ectropion . Ectropion: Type of Ectropion Description Causes Clinical Features Treatment Involutional Ectropion Most common; age-related Horizontal laxity Canthal tendon laxity Epiphora Tarsal thinning Lagophthalmos Medial conjunctivoplasty for mild cases. Horizontal lid shortening for moderate cases. Byron Smith's modified Kuhnt-Szymanowski operation for severe cases. Lateral tarsal strip technique for generalized ectropion. Cicatricial Ectropion Scarring of anterior lamella Trauma/surgery Scarring conditions (e.g., blepharitis) Scarring Skin fibrosis Mild cases: V-Y operation. (Option B) Mild to moderate cases: Z-plasty (Elschnig's operation). Severe cases: Excision of scar tissue and full-thickness skin grafting. Paralytic Ectropion Facial nerve palsy (Bell’s) Bell’s palsy Trauma/surgery Exposure keratopathy Temporary measures: Topical lubricants, eyelid taping, suture tarsorrhaphy. Permanent measures (if needed): Horizontal lid tightening with/without middle lamellar buttress, palpebral sling operation. Mechanical Ectropion Mass or lesion pushing eyelid Tumors Conjunctival growths Eyelid displacement Conjunctival chemosis Treat the underlying mechanical causes. Congenital Ectropion Present at birth Tarsal plate atrophy Down syndrome Associated eyelid malformation Mild cases may not require treatment. Moderate or severe cases: Horizontal lid tightening and full-thickness skin graft. V-Y procedures have NO benefit in treatment of Entropion (Option A) , Blepharophimosis (Option C) and Ptosis (Option D) . Reference: Yanoff & Duker - Ophthalmology 5th edition, page 1281 Kanski’s Clinical Ophthalmology 9th edition page 85-87

questions.question: Please identify the medical condition depicted in the provided image.
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) Entropion Explanation: The above image shows inward rolling of the lower lid margin towards the globe, which is suggestive of Entropion. Grading of entropion: Grade-I Only the posterior lid border is in-rolled Grade-II includes in-rolling up to the intermarginal strip Grade-III Whole lid margin including the anterior border is in-rolled Types of Entropion: Type Description Etiology 1) Congenital Entropion Present since birth, more common in the lower eyelid Lower Eyelid: Improper development of lower lid retractors. Upper Eyelid: Mechanical effects due to microphthalmos. 2) Cicatricial Entropion Commonly involves the upper eyelid. Common causes: Trachoma , chemical burns, pemphigus, Stevens-Johnson syndrome, symblepharon. 3) Senile (Involutional) Entropion Affects the lower eyelid in elderly individuals . Horizontal lid laxity Vertical lid instability Overriding of pretarsal orbicularis. Laxity of orbital septum 4) Mechanical Entropion Lack of support from the globe to the lids. Occurs in conditions like phthisis bulbi , enophthalmos and after enucleation or evisceration operations. Ectropion (Option B): Outward rolling of the eyelid away from the globe. Trichiasis (Option C): Misdirection of the eyelids. Ptosis (Option D): Drooping of the eyelid of the eyelid is known as ptosis.

questions.question: All of the following are features of oculomotor nerve palsy except?
questions.explanation: feature of oculomotor nerve palsy. This movement is controlled by the lateral rectus muscle, which is innervated by the abducens nerve (cranial nerve VI). Dysfunction of the abducens nerve leads to issues with abduction, not the oculomotor nerve. Incorrect Options : Option A, B, and D: . Oculomotor nerve palsy, or third nerve palsy, typically presents with several distinct features due to the dysfunction of the muscles and structures innervated by the oculomotor nerve (cranial nerve III). These features include: Ptosis : Drooping of the upper eyelid due to paralysis of the levator palpebrae superioris muscle. Exotropia : Outward deviation of the eye because the medial rectus muscle (which normally pulls the eye inward) is paralyzed. Dilated pupil : Also known as mydriasis, this occurs because the oculomotor nerve controls the constrictor pupillae muscle, and its dysfunction leads to unopposed action of the dilator pupillae muscle. Reference: .

questions.question: All of the following are functions of superior oblique muscle except?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) Adduction Explanation: The superior oblique muscle primarily causes: Abduction (moves the eye outward, away from the midline) Depression (moves the eye downward when it is adducted) Intorsion (rotates the top of the eye toward the nose) It does not cause adduction , which is moving the eye inward toward the nose; that is the function of the medial rectus . Actions of Extraocular Muscles Muscle Primary Actions Superior oblique Abduction, depression (in adducted eye), intorsion Inferior oblique Abduction, elevation (in adducted eye), extorsion Medial rectus Adduction Lateral rectus Abduction Superior rectus Elevation (in abducted eye), intorsion, slight adduction Inferior rectus Depression (in abducted eye), extorsion, slight adduction Abduction (Option B): Correct function of superior oblique. Depression (Option C): Correct function of superior oblique when eye is adducted. Intorsion (Option D): Correct function of superior oblique. Reference: .Grey's Anatomy 42nd edition, pg 773-777. BD Chaurasia’s Human Anatomy, 8th edition, pg 232-237. Vishram Singh Textbook of Anatomy, 2nd edition, pg 285-288.

questions.question: What is the order of insertion of muscles on Annulus of Zinn? A. Medial rectus
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) A, B, C, D Explanation: Medial rectus > inferior rectus > lateral rectus > Spiral of tillaux Origin Insertion Nerve supply Recti Common annular tendon or tendinous ring of Zinn. (all recti have the same origin) Sclera little posterior to the limbus (corneoscleral junction) The average distance from Limbus is: Superior: 7.7 mm Inferior: 6.5 mm Medial: 5.5 mm Lateral: 6.9 mm Superior oblique: Trochlear nerve Lateral rectus: Abducens nerve Rest all other recti: Oculomotor nerve Options B, C, and D are incorrect. Reference: Grey's Anatomy 42nd edition, pg 773-777. BD Chaurasia’s Human Anatomy, 8th edition, pg 232-237. Vishram Singh Textbook of Anatomy, 2nd edition, pg 285-288.

questions.question: A 3-month-old child was brought to the outpatient department (OPD) with symptoms of photophobia and watering of the eyes. Which of the following is not a cause of this condition? Congenital distichiasis

options.A: Congenital nasolacrimal duct obstruction B) Congenital entropion C) Congenital glaucoma D)

questions.explanation: openings of the meibomian glands along the posterior margin of the eyelid. It doesnot necessarily touch the cornea like entropion therefore its less likely to cause lacrimation and photophobia among the given options Distichiasis - Extra row of eyelash Clinical features Foreign body sensation Photophobia, in cases of corneal irritation Irritation Pain Lacrimation, in cases of corneal irritation Reflex blepharospasm and photophobia (if the cornea is abraded) Conjunctival congestion Complications Recurrent corneal abrasions Superficial corneal opacities Corneal vascularization Non-healing corneal ulcer Treatment Epilation Electrolysis Cryoepilation Surgical correction Options A, B, and C: All of these conditions present with photophobia and watering of the eye. Reference: Kanski’s Clinical Ophthalmology 9th edition page 62-63

questions.question: What is the likely diagnosis for a patient who has a painless, firm nodule on the upper eyelid that is growing away from the lid margin?
questions.explanation: margin is a classic presentation of a chalazion. It is typically painless but can cause discomfort or cosmetic concerns if it becomes large. Incorrect Options: Option A - Stye: A stye, also known as a hordeolum externum, is a painful, red, tender lump in the lid margin pointing anteriorly through the lid margin commonly caused by staphylococcus aureus... Option B - Entropion: Entropion is a condition in which the eyelid turns inward, causing the lashes to rub against the eye's surface. It can cause irritation, redness, and tearing. Option D - Blepharitis: Blepharitis is a chronic inflammation of the eyelids that can cause redness, itching, and flaking of the eyelid skin. Reference: ,

questions.question: In a patient presenting with recurrent chalazion, which cancer should be suspected?
questions.explanation: sebaceous cell carcinoma, which is a rare but aggressive malignancy originating from the sebaceous glands. Sebaceous cell carcinoma can mimic chalazion-like lesions, making it important to consider this cancer in cases of persistent or recurrent chalazion. Incorrect Options: Options B, C, and D are incorrect. Refer to Option A for axplanation.

questions.question: Internal hordeolum is due to inflammation of
questions.explanation: caused by the infection or blockage of the Meibomian glands. The Meibomian glands are specialized sebaceous glands located along the eyelid margin. When the Meibomian glands become obstructed or infected, typically due to bacterial colonization, it can lead to the development of an internal hordeolum. This causes localized inflammation and the formation of a painful, red lump on the inside of the eyelid. Incorrect Options: Options A, C, and D are incorrect. Internal hordeolum is due to the inflammation of Meibomian gland.

questions.question: Which of the following is characterized by chronic granulomatous inflammation in the upper eyelid, causing painless swelling?
questions.explanation: inflammation of the meibomian glands. It presents as a painless, firm swelling on the upper or lower eyelid. It is caused by blockage and subsequent inflammation of the oil glands. Histopathology shows a lipo granulomatous chronic inflammatory picture with extracellular fat deposits surrounded by lipid-laden epithelioid cells, multinucleated giant cells, and lymphocytes. Incorrect options: Option A - Internal hordeolum: This refers to an infection of the meibomian glands, which are located in the eyelid. It typically presents as a painful, red lump on the eyelid margin. Option B - External hordeolum: Also known as a stye, it is an infection of the eyelash follicle or associated glands. It appears as a painful, red bump on the outside of the eyelid. Option D - Trachoma is a contagious bacterial infection caused by Chlamydia trachomatis. It primarily affects the conjunctiva and can lead to scarring and distortion of the eyelid.

questions.question: What is the recommended course of treatment for mild congenital ptosis?
questions.explanation: mullerectomy. It is performed in cases having mild ptosis (1.5-2 mm) and good levator function. In it, the upper lid is everted and the upper tarsal border, along with its attached Muller's muscle and conjunctiva are resected. Incorrect options Options A and B - Blaskowic’s and Everbusch’s operation is done for moderate ptosis (3 mm), it involves resection of LPS muscle. Option D - Frontalis Sling operation: Frontalis Sling operation is performed for severe ptosis (4 mm), it involves resection of frontalis muscle.

questions.question: What is the appropriate treatment for ptosis resulting from Horner's syndrome?
questions.explanation: Mild ptosis due to paralysis of Muller's muscle. Miosis due to paralysis of dilator pupillae. Ipsilateral anhydrosis. The treatment of choice for mild ptosis due to Muller’s muscle paralysis is Fasanella-Servat operation, aka Tarso-conjunctiva muller ectomy, which involves resection of Muller’s muscle, providing strength. Incorrect Options: Options A and D - Blaskowic’s and Everbusch’s operation is done for moderate ptosis (3 mm), it involves resection of LPS muscle. Option B - Frontalis Sling operation: Frontalis Sling operation is performed for severe ptosis (4 mm), it involves resection of frontalis muscle. Reference: .

questions.question: What is the most frequently observed eye manifestation in this disease in a 45-year-old patient who presents with progressive weakness throughout the day and is found to possess antibodies against nicotinic acetylcholine receptors?
questions.explanation: the day, along with the presence of antibodies against nicotinic acetylcholine receptors, suggests the diagnosis of myasthenia gravis . Myasthenia gravis is an autoimmune disorder characterized by muscle weakness and fatigue , particularly in the muscles controlled by voluntary movements. Ocular features of myasthenia gravis are ptosis (bilateral), diplopia, and nystagmus in extreme gazes. Incorrect Options: Options A, B, and C are incorrect. Refer to Option D for an explanation.

questions.question: In a case of long-standing, uncontrolled diabetes, what is the most common characteristic of third nerve palsy?
questions.explanation: cases of long-standing, uncontrolled diabetes. Ocular manifestation seen in third nerve palsy are: A - Profound ptosis due to weakness of the levator muscle. B - Abduction and depression in the primary position due to unopposed action of the lateral rectus and superior oblique muscles. C - Normal abduction as the lateral rectus is intact D - Limited adduction due to medial rectus weakness. E - Limited elevation due to weakness of the superior rectus and inferior oblique. F - Limited depression due to weakness of the inferior rectus. G - Dilated pupil and defective accommodation due to parasympathetic palsy. Incorrect Options: Options A, B, and D are incorrect. Refer to Option C for an explanation.
